relation: おとうとさんのなまえはＭＡＡＫＵです.doc View Download

Years ago I borrowed this idea from a teacher in the Lower Mainland. Have the students make a 5 by 5 grid and write the Japanese vocabulary currently being studied in squares. Japanese only, no English translations. The teacher then does Bingo by calling out the English words. The students must find the Japanese equivalents on their bingo grid and try and get 5 in a row. The winner is presented with the ビンゴ さま award in a ceremony infront of the class. I allow the students to hand in the awards for bonus marks at the end of the term. Submitted by Bradley
Here is a hiragana diagram also available for teachers to edit to suit their needs, to create their own blackline master. Submitted by jchiu

This is a blackline master of the katakana characters. Even if you already have a blackline master from a textbook, it is still nice to have the data on word processor so you can edit it to suit your needs. (i.e. change the Asian font, enlargement, minimise, etc.) Submitted by jchiu
Blank template for particle practice game. Submitted by Grace Ho.
Puzzle for beginner students practicing hiragana. Based on key pad on Japanese cell phones Submitted by Sachiko R
All the vocabulary from Ch 3 of Kimono 1, in kana, romaji and English. Submitted by KarenC
Practice questions with vocabulary from Kimono 1 Ch 4. Submitted by KarenC
review sheet for vocabulary from Kimono 1 Chapter 5 Submitted by KarenC
This is a way for the students to discover the rule for writing a double consonant in Hiragana by themselves. Submitted by Bradley
A worksheet for Japanesepo101.com Beginner Lesson #23 - Bringing it all together

Once students have learned to do self-introductions, this is a fun practice. Copy and cut out the fictional information cards for famous people. Students introduce themselves to each other with their new identity as if the famous person was in high school. This information includes name, age, home location and telephone number. Submitted by Bradley
Useful classroom expressions list in hiragana, roomaji, and English for the beginner students. Submitted by Sachiko_R

The students discover how to create past tense and present/future tense by themselves. They are given a series of sentences and must discover "masu" and "mashita" from clues given. Submitted by Bradley
Grave of the Fireflies This bonus activity looks at various websites on the anime and drama "Grave of the Fireflies" (Hotaru no Haka). Submitted by Sachiko_R
Sudoku puzzle using hiragana characters ???????? Submitted by wendyky

Hiragana Sudoku puzzle using the characters te, to, na, ni, nu, ne, no, ha, hi Submitted by wendyky
Hiragana Sudoku puzzle using the characters fu, he, ho, ma, mi, mu, me, mo, ya Submitted by wendyky
Hiragana Sudoku puzzle using the characters yu, yo, ra, ri, ru, re, ro, wa, wo Submitted by wendyky

This activity is a fantasy travel project in Japan. The students will need vocabulary for modes of transportation and need to understand how to use で to talk about "by" and "at" . You will need a map of Japan too. Submitted by Bradley
Particle Practice Game. Submitted by Grace Ho.
Nagatomi-sensei's handouts from her workshop "Jump Start from Day 1" at the BCATML Conference 2009.
Since Kimono(1) does not introduce "tomodachi to" until chapter 4 this is a supplementary dialogue done in roomagi. Submitted by Dan
Trivia Game about numbers related to Japan
Uno, with basic colors and numbers.
A weather activity created by Jennifer Shirota. The activity was created for Kimono 2, Chapter 3, but is independent of the textbook and can be used for any weather unit. Submitted by Bradley
